bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Paul L. Tate, February 27, 1956

div1.p: Hench concludes that Lambert's fight for Ames was really a fight for himself. Hench states that the original yellow fever bill should not be changed.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Paul L. Tate, February 27, 1956
div1.opener:
February 27, 1956
Mr. Paul Tate
1530 Tyler Street
Berkeley, California
My dear Mr. Tate:
div1.p:
Thank you for your information about the bill for Lambert. Is Doctor Ames
being included? All these years that Lambert has been contacting his Congress-
man and so on, he was ostensibly putting up a strong fight for the memory of
Doctor Ames. Of course I knew all along that his fight for Doctor Ames was
also a fight for Lambert.

Please don't misunderstand me. I am very fond of Mr. Lambert and would do
absolutely nothing to hurt his feelings. Having talked to some pretty “high
ups” in the Pentagon in the last several years with respect to the yellow
fever bill, and having myself spoken in favor of some honor (though not the
same medal) for Doctor Ames and Mr. Lambert, I became convinced that the
original yellow fever bill would never be changed and that my best way of
honoring Ames and Lambert was to mention them and show their pictures in
every lecture I gave and to bring out in my papers and books exactly what
they did.

Now do you know whether Doctor Ames was included or excluded and if he was
excluded, was it because Lambert got weary of fighting for Ames or did
Lambert's Congressman decide to fight only for Lambert, the living, and not
for Ames, the dead? Confidentially, how do you feel about Congress honoring
Lambert without including Ames or at least the memory of Ames? If I can
help, I want to do so and I am very sincere in saying that I will do anything
I can to honor Lambert but I certainly would like to see Ames honored also.
What do you think? I shall appreciate hearing from you promptly.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
